    24- [x] **Date navigation** - Previous/next day buttons, calendar picker
    25- [x] **DatePicker** - Full calendar modal for jumping to specific dates (`src/components/DatePicker.jsx`)
    26- [x] **DailyProgress** - Visual progress bars for calories and macros (`src/components/DailyProgress.jsx`)
    27- [x] **EntryList** - Display food entries with edit/delete options (`src/components/EntryList.jsx`)
    28- [x] **EntryForm** - Slide-up form for adding/editing entries (`src/components/EntryForm.jsx`)
    29- [x] **Modal** - Confirmation dialogs for destructive actions (`src/components/Modal.jsx`)
    30- [x] **Settings** - Goals configuration, data import/export (`src/components/Settings.jsx`)
    31- [x] **FAB** - Floating action button for quick entry adding (`src/components/FAB.jsx`)
    32- [x] **App** - Main component wiring all features together (`src/components/App.jsx`)
    33

# Calorie Tracker

A local-first calorie and macro tracking web app built with Preact and Vite. Data is stored in the browser using IndexedDB and localStorage.

## Tech Stack

- **Framework:** Preact + Vite
- **Storage:** IndexedDB (food entries), localStorage (user goals, profiles)
- **Styling:** CSS with custom properties (Ocean Coral theme)
- **Deployment:** GitHub Pages

## What's Been Implemented

### Core Features (MVP)

- [x] **Project scaffolding** - Vite + Preact setup with build tooling
- [x] **IndexedDB storage** - `src/utils/db.js` for persistent food entry storage
- [x] **localStorage goals** - `src/utils/storage.js` for daily calorie/macro targets
- [x] **Date utilities** - `src/utils/date.js` for date formatting and navigation

### UI Components

- [x] **Header** - App title, settings access, profile display (`src/components/Header.jsx`)
- [x] **Date navigation** - Previous/next day buttons, calendar picker
- [x] **DatePicker** - Full calendar modal for jumping to specific dates (`src/components/DatePicker.jsx`)
- [x] **DailyProgress** - Visual progress bars for calories and macros (`src/components/DailyProgress.jsx`)
- [x] **EntryList** - Display food entries with edit/delete options (`src/components/EntryList.jsx`)
- [x] **EntryForm** - Slide-up form for adding/editing entries (`src/components/EntryForm.jsx`)
- [x] **Modal** - Confirmation dialogs for destructive actions (`src/components/Modal.jsx`)
- [x] **Settings** - Goals configuration, data import/export (`src/components/Settings.jsx`)
- [x] **FAB** - Floating action button for quick entry adding (`src/components/FAB.jsx`)
- [x] **App** - Main component wiring all features together (`src/components/App.jsx`)

### Data Management

- [x] **Add entries** - Food name, calories, protein, carbs, fat
- [x] **Edit entries** - Modify existing food entries
- [x] **Delete entries** - With confirmation modal
- [x] **Date-based filtering** - View entries by date
- [x] **Data export** - Export all data to JSON
- [x] **Data import** - Import from JSON backup

### Multi-User Profiles

- [x] **Profile storage** - Create, delete, switch profiles with PIN protection
- [x] **Profile-aware data** - Entries and goals scoped per profile
- [x] **Profile picker** - Modal to select active profile
- [x] **Profile management** - Settings section for profile CRUD
- [x] **Data migration** - Migrate legacy single-user data to first profile
- [x] **ProfileSettings component** - `src/components/ProfileSettings.jsx`

### Theming & Styling

- [x] **Ocean Coral theme** - Teal primary + coral accents (was sage green)
- [x] **Responsive design** - Mobile-first, max-width 480px
- [x] **Animations** - Fade in, slide up, scale in transitions
- [x] **CSS custom properties** - Easy theming via `:root` variables

### Deployment

- [x] **GitHub Actions workflow** - `.github/workflows/deploy.yml`
- [x] **Vite build config** - Relative base path for GitHub Pages

## What's Left To Do

### Suggested Future Features

- [ ] **PWA support** - Service worker, offline mode, install prompt
- [ ] **Food database** - Search common foods for quick entry
- [ ] **Meal templates** - Save frequent meals for one-tap logging
- [ ] **Statistics/trends** - Weekly/monthly calorie/macro summaries
- [ ] **Weight tracking** - Log and graph body weight over time
- [ ] **Meal photos** - Attach images to food entries
- [ ] **Barcode scanning** - Scan products for nutritional info
- [ ] **Voice input** - Add entries via voice commands
- [ ] **Dark mode** - Toggle between light/dark themes
- [ ] **Notifications** - Meal reminders
- [ ] **Data sync** - Optional cloud backup/sync

### Code Quality

- [ ] **Unit tests** - Test utility functions and components
- [ ] **E2E tests** - Test user flows
- [ ] **TypeScript migration** - Type safety
- [ ] **Accessibility audit** - Ensure WCAG compliance
- [ ] **Performance audit** - Lighthouse optimization

## Project Structure

```
src/
  index.jsx           # App entry point
  styles.css          # Global styles with CSS variables
  components/
    App.jsx           # Main app component
    Header.jsx        # App header with navigation
    DailyProgress.jsx # Calorie/macro progress bars
    EntryList.jsx     # List of food entries
    EntryForm.jsx     # Add/edit entry form
    DatePicker.jsx    # Calendar date picker
    Modal.jsx         # Confirmation dialog
    Settings.jsx      # Goals and data settings
    ProfileSettings.jsx # Multi-user profile management
    FAB.jsx           # Floating action button
  utils/
    db.js             # IndexedDB operations
    storage.js        # localStorage operations (goals, profiles)
    date.js           # Date formatting helpers
docs/
  plans/              # Implementation plans
```

## Running Locally

```bash
npm install
npm run dev     # Start dev server at localhost:5173
npm run build   # Production build to dist/
npm run preview # Preview production build
```

## Key Implementation Notes

- **IndexedDB v2** includes composite index `profileDate` for efficient profile+date queries
- **Profiles** are optional - app works in single-user mode without profiles
- **Migration** automatically prompts existing users to create a profile and migrates their data
- **PIN protection** is basic privacy (stored in localStorage, not secure)
- **Export/import** allows full data backup in JSON format

# Calorie Tracker

Local-first calorie/macro tracking app. Browser storage only (IndexedDB + localStorage).

## Tech Stack

- **Framework:** Preact + Vite
- **Storage:** IndexedDB (entries), localStorage (goals, profiles)
- **Styling:** CSS custom properties (Ocean Coral theme)
- **Deploy:** GitHub Pages via `.github/workflows/deploy.yml`

## Project Structure

```
src/
  components/     # Preact components (App, Header, EntryForm, etc.)
  utils/
    db.js         # IndexedDB operations
    storage.js    # localStorage (goals, profiles)
    date.js       # Date helpers
```

## Run Commands

```bash
npm run dev      # localhost:5173
npm run build    # Production build
```

## Key Implementation Notes

- **IndexedDB v2** has composite index `profileDate` for profile+date queries
- **Profiles** optional - works in single-user mode without them
- **Migration** auto-prompts existing users to create profile and migrates data
- **PIN** is basic privacy only (localStorage, not cryptographically secure)

## Current State

MVP complete: entries, goals, date navigation, profiles, import/export. Mobile-first (max-width 480px).

# Design  Design Ops Flywheel

Orchestrate the full design workflow from idea to implementation-ready specs.

**System location:** `~/obsidian/sa-intel/_System/Design/`
**Templates:** `_System/Design/Templates/`
**Domains:** `_System/Design/Domains/`

## Usage

```
/design {project}                      # Auto-detect mode, full workflow
/design {project} full                 # Force full mode
/design {project} standard             # Force standard mode
/design {project} minimal              # Force minimal mode
/design {project} research             # Research phase only
/design {project} journey              # Journey phase only
/design {project} spec                 # Spec phase only
/design {project} validate {artifact}  # Validate specific artifact
/design {project} retrospective        # Post-implementation review
```

---

## Mode Detection

**If mode not specified, analyze the request:**

| Signal | Mode |
|--------|------|
| "new product", "build from scratch", "greenfield" | Full |
| "feature", "add", "implement", multiple components | Standard |
| "fix", "bug", "tweak", "update", single component | Minimal |
| Unclear | Ask user |

**Mode comparison:**

| Phase | Full | Standard | Minimal |
|-------|------|----------|---------|
| Research + Validation |  2 iterations |  1 iteration |  |
| Constraints |  |  |  |
| Brainstorm |  | Optional |  |
| Tracer Bullet |  |  |  |
| Personas | If needed |  |  |
| Journeys + Validation |  2 iterations |  1 iteration |  |
| Tokens |  | Reuse existing | Reuse existing |
| Specs + Validation |  2 iterations |  1 iteration |  no validation |
| Tests + Validation |  2 iterations |  1 iteration |  no validation |
| Retrospective |  |  | Optional |

---

## Phase 1: Research

**Purpose:** Gather domain expertise, prior art, cross-domain inspiration before designing.

**Process:**

1. **Identify domain context:**
   - What industry/domain is this for?
   - Who are the users?
   - What's the emotional goal? (trust, speed, delight, calm)

2. **Find domain experts and legends:**
   - Search: "{domain} UX experts", "{domain} design leaders"
   - Look for books, talks, case studies
   - Minimum 3 distinct sources

3. **Analyze prior art:**
   - Direct competitors (how do they solve this?)
   - Adjacent products (similar problems, different domain)
   - Anti-patterns (what to avoid, why it failed)

4. **Cross-domain inspiration:**
   - Physical architecture (Tadao Ando, Frank Lloyd Wright)
   - Industrial design (Dieter Rams, Jony Ive)
   - Art/visual (Bauhaus, Swiss design, Japanese Ma)
   - Unexpected domains (gaming, aviation, medical devices)

5. **Generate token recommendations:**
   - Typography that fits the domain
   - Color palette with semantic meaning
   - Spacing philosophy

**Check domain library first:** `_System/Design/Domains/{domain}.md`

**Output:** `{project}/docs/design/research.md`

```markdown
# Research: {project}

id: R-001
date: {YYYY-MM-DD}
domain: {domain}

## Domain Context

**Industry:** {industry}
**Users:** {primary users}
**Emotional Goal:** {trust/speed/delight/calm/etc.}

## Domain Experts & Legends

| Expert | Known For | Key Insight |
|--------|-----------|-------------|
| {name} | {contribution} | {one-liner} |

## Prior Art

### Direct Competitors

| Product | Strength | Weakness | Steal This |
|---------|----------|----------|------------|
| {product} | {what they do well} | {what they miss} | {pattern to adopt} |

### Adjacent Inspiration

| Source | Domain | Pattern | Apply How |
|--------|--------|---------|-----------|
| {source} | {their domain} | {pattern} | {how we use it} |

### Anti-Patterns

| Source | Failure | Lesson |
|--------|---------|--------|
| {product} | {what went wrong} | {what to avoid} |

## Cross-Domain Inspiration

| Domain | Source | Insight |
|--------|--------|---------|
| Architecture | {who} | {what we learn} |
| Industrial Design | {who} | {what we learn} |
| Art/Visual | {movement} | {what we learn} |

## Token Recommendations

### Typography
- **Primary:** {font}  {why}
- **Secondary:** {font}  {why}

### Color
| Token | Value | Meaning |
|-------|-------|---------|
| Primary | {hex} | {semantic meaning} |
| Success | {hex} | {semantic meaning} |
| Warning | {hex} | {semantic meaning} |
| Danger | {hex} | {semantic meaning} |

### Principles Derived
1. {principle from research}
2. {principle from research}
3. {principle from research}
```

---

## Phase 1.5: Research Validation

**Purpose:** Stress test research before it poisons everything downstream.

**Run these checks:**

### Check 1: Echo Chamber Detection

Prompt yourself:
- How many distinct sources did I cite?
- Do they all share the same perspective?
- What perspectives are missing? (critics, competitors, adjacent fields)
- Am I only finding what I want to find?

**Pass criteria:** 3+ distinct sources, at least 1 contrarian viewpoint

### Check 2: Staleness Check

- Are any sources older than 2 years?
- Is the competitive landscape current?
- Any deprecated technologies mentioned?

**Pass criteria:** All sources current or marked as "timeless principles"

### Check 3: Domain Drift Detection

- Does research match the ACTUAL problem?
- Are the users described the ACTUAL users?
- Would following this research solve the stated problem?

**Pass criteria:** Research directly addresses problem statement

### Check 4: Missing Competitors

- List all competitors mentioned
- Who's NOT mentioned that should be?
- Are strengths AND weaknesses analyzed?

**Pass criteria:** 2+ competitors, balanced analysis

### Check 5: Assumption Surfacing

- What does research assume about users?
- What does it assume about technical environment?
- What "everybody knows" statements might be wrong?

**Pass criteria:** Assumptions explicitly stated

**Validation loop:**
1. Run all 5 checks
2. Fix issues found
3. Re-run checks
4. Minimum 2 iterations before proceeding

**Output:** `{project}/docs/design/research-validation.md`

---

## Phase 2: Constraints

**Purpose:** Capture boundaries before designing within them.

**Gather:**

1. **Technical Boundaries:**
   - Stack (frameworks, languages, infrastructure)
   - Deployment (where, how, who)
   - Auth (method, provider)
   - Integrations (what systems)

2. **Performance Budgets:**
   - Load time targets
   - Bundle size limits
   - API response times

3. **Resource Reality:**
   - Timeline (fixed? flexible?)
   - Team (who, skills)
   - Budget (if relevant)

4. **Non-Negotiables:**
   - Must-haves that cannot be cut
   - Accessibility requirements
   - Compliance requirements

5. **Explicit Descopes:**
   - What we're NOT building
   - What we're deferring
   - Why (document the decision)

**Output:** `{project}/docs/design/constraints.md`

---

## Phase 3: Brainstorm

**Purpose:** Turn research + constraints into requirements through dialogue.

**Process:**
1. Invoke `superpowers:brainstorming` skill
2. Load research summary as context
3. Load constraints as boundaries
4. Explore requirements through conversation
5. Document in requirements.md

**Output:** `{project}/docs/design/requirements.md`

---

## Phase 3.5: Tracer Bullet (Full mode only)

**Purpose:** Validate assumptions with minimal end-to-end implementation.

**Process:**
1. Pick ONE journey (the riskiest or most uncertain)
2. Build it end-to-end, ugly but functional
3. Don't polish  just make it work
4. Document what you learned
5. Adjust remaining specs based on learnings

> "Tracer bullets show what you're hitting. They illuminate the path from requirement to system."  Pragmatic Programmer

**Output:** Working code + learnings documented

---

## Phase 4: Personas (if needed)

**Purpose:** Create reusable actor profiles for distinct user types.

**When to create:**
- Multiple distinct user types with different goals
- User context significantly affects design decisions
- "User" is too vague to design for

**Persona structure:**

```markdown
# Persona: {name}

id: P-{NNN}

## Identity
**Name:** {representative name}
**Role:** {job title}
**Archetype:** {e.g., "The Busy Executive"}

## Goals
**Primary:** {main objective}
**Success Metric:** {how they measure success}

## Context
**Environment:** {where they work}
**Devices:** {what they use}
**Time Pressure:** {low/medium/high}
**Technical Skill:** {novice/intermediate/expert}

## Pain Points
| Pain | Frequency | Severity |
|------|-----------|----------|
| {frustration} | {daily/weekly} | {low/med/high} |

## Quote
> "{Something they'd actually say}"

## Design Implications
| Trait | Design Response |
|-------|-----------------|
| {trait} | {how we accommodate} |
```

**Output:** `{project}/docs/design/personas/P-001-{name}.md`

---

## Phase 5: User Journeys

**Purpose:** Map user paths through the system with emotional awareness.

**For each journey:**

1. **Define the journey:**
   - Actor (persona or specific user type)
   - Goal (what they're trying to accomplish)
   - Context (when, where, why)
   - Entry point (how they get here)
   - Exit point (where they go next)

2. **Map the happy path (Mermaid):**
```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[Starting point] --> B{Decision?}
    B -->|Yes| C[Path A]
    B -->|No| D[Path B]
    C --> E[Outcome]
    D --> E
```

3. **Add emotional arc:**

| Stage | User Feeling | Design Response |
|-------|--------------|-----------------|
| Entry | {emotion} | {how we address it} |
| Discovery | {emotion} | {how we address it} |
| Action | {emotion} | {how we address it} |
| Completion | {emotion} | {how we address it} |

4. **Document edge cases:**
   - What if they make a mistake?
   - What if the system fails?
   - What if they abandon mid-flow?
   - What if data is missing?

5. **Document error paths:**
   - At least 2 error scenarios
   - How user recovers
   - What they see

**Output:** `{project}/docs/design/journeys/J-001-{name}.md`

---

## Phase 5.5: Journey Validation

**Purpose:** Stress test journeys before they drive specs.

**Run these checks:**

### Check 1: Happy Path Bias

- What happens if user makes a mistake at each step?
- What happens if system fails at each step?
- What happens if user abandons mid-journey?

**Pass criteria:** 2+ error paths documented

### Check 2: Actor Vagueness

- Is actor specific enough to design for?
- Can you picture this person?
- Would two developers imagine the same person?

**Pass criteria:** Actor has context, goals, constraints

### Check 3: Reality Check

- Does flow assume uninterrupted focus?
- Does it assume perfect conditions?
- Does it assume user reads everything?
- Are timing estimates realistic?

**Pass criteria:** Assumptions are realistic for context

### Check 4: Missing Decision Points

- Are there implicit choices not shown?
- What if user wants to go back/undo?
- Are permission checks shown?

**Pass criteria:** All branches documented

### Check 5: Emotional Arc

- Is user feeling documented at each stage?
- Are anxiety points addressed?
- Does ending feel satisfying?

**Pass criteria:** Emotional arc complete

### Check 6: Journey Bloat

- More than 10 steps? (Split it)
- More than 3 decision points? (Simplify)
- Actually multiple journeys? (Split it)

**Pass criteria:** Right-sized journey

**Validation loop:** Minimum 2 iterations

**Output:** `{project}/docs/design/journeys/J-001-validation.md`

---

## Phase 6: Design Tokens

**Purpose:** Codify visual design decisions as reusable tokens.

**Check domain library first:** `_System/Design/Domains/{domain}.md`

**Token categories:**

1. **Typography:**
   - Font families (primary, secondary, mono)
   - Size scale (xs through 4xl)
   - Weights (normal, medium, semibold, bold)
   - Line heights

2. **Colors:**
   - Semantic palette (primary, success, warning, danger, neutral)
   - With contrast ratios documented
   - Light and dark variants

3. **Spacing:**
   - Base unit (usually 4px or 8px)
   - Scale (1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 12, 16, etc.)

4. **Borders & Radius:**
   - Border widths
   - Radius scale (sm, md, lg, full)

5. **Shadows:**
   - Elevation scale (sm, md, lg, xl)

6. **Motion:**
   - Duration scale (fast, normal, slow)
   - Easing functions
   - Reduced motion alternatives

7. **Component tokens:**
   - Button variants
   - Input states
   - Card styles

**Output:** `{project}/docs/design/tokens.md`

---

## Phase 7: Specs

**Purpose:** Ralph-style exhaustive specifications.

**For each feature/component:**

```markdown
# Spec: {feature-name}

id: S-{NNN}
journey: J-{NNN}
version: 1.0
status: draft

## Purpose

{Why this exists, what problem it solves}

## Interface Contract

### Props/Inputs
| Prop | Type | Required | Default | Description |
|------|------|----------|---------|-------------|

### State
| State | Type | Initial | Description |
|-------|------|---------|-------------|

### Events/Outputs
| Event | Payload | When Fired |
|-------|---------|------------|

## Component Breakdown

| Component | Responsibility | Children |
|-----------|----------------|----------|

## State Machine

```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> Idle
    Idle --> Loading: fetch
    Loading --> Success: data
    Loading --> Error: fail
    Error --> Loading: retry
    Success --> [*]
```

## Visual Spec

{ASCII diagram or reference to design file}

## Behavior

### Happy Path
1. {step}
2. {step}

### Error Handling
| Error | User Sees | Recovery |
|-------|-----------|----------|

### Edge Cases
| Case | Behavior |
|------|----------|

## Accessibility

- [ ] Keyboard navigable
- [ ] Screen reader friendly
- [ ] Color contrast 4.5:1
- [ ] Focus indicators visible
- [ ] Reduced motion respected

## Performance

| Metric | Target |
|--------|--------|
| First render | <{X}ms |
| Interaction | <{X}ms |
| Bundle size | <{X}KB |

## Definition of Done

- [ ] All acceptance criteria met
- [ ] Tests passing
- [ ] Accessibility validated
- [ ] Performance validated
- [ ] Documentation updated
- [ ] Code reviewed
- [ ] Deployed to staging
- [ ] Actually used it yourself
```

**Output:** `{project}/docs/design/specs/S-001-{name}.md`

---

## Phase 7.5: Spec Validation

**Purpose:** Stress test specs before deriving tests.

**Run these checks:**

### Check 1: Ambiguity Detection

- Can any requirement be interpreted two ways?
- Are there implicit assumptions?
- Where does spec use vague language?

**Pass criteria:** Unambiguous, specific requirements

### Check 2: Edge Case Generation

- Boundary conditions covered? (empty, one, many, max)
- Invalid inputs handled?
- Timing issues addressed?
- State transitions complete?

**Pass criteria:** All edge cases documented

### Check 3: Implementation Simulation

Walk through as a developer:
- What would you build first?
- Where do you have to guess?
- What would you invent?

**Pass criteria:** Spec is sufficient to implement

### Check 4: Contradiction Detection

- Do any requirements conflict?
- Any mutually exclusive states?
- Any circular dependencies?

**Pass criteria:** Internally consistent

**Validation loop:** Minimum 2 iterations

**Output:** `{project}/docs/design/specs/S-001-validation.md`

---

## Phase 8: Tests

**Purpose:** Multi-layer test contracts before implementation.

**Test structure:**

```markdown
# Tests: {feature-name}

id: T-{NNN}
spec: S-{NNN}

## Functional Tests

### Scenario: {name}

**Given:** {precondition}
**When:** {action}
**Then:** {expected outcome}
**And:** {additional assertions}

## Non-Functional Tests

### Performance
| Metric | Target | Test Method |
|--------|--------|-------------|

### Accessibility
| Check | Tool | Pass Criteria |
|-------|------|---------------|

### Security
| Check | Method | Pass Criteria |
|-------|--------|---------------|

## LLM-as-Judge Tests

### Quality Gate: {name}

**Evaluation Prompt:**
```
You are evaluating implementation against design requirements.

ORIGINAL JOURNEY:
{paste journey}

DESIGN PRINCIPLES:
{list principles}

IMPLEMENTATION:
{screenshot or output}

EVALUATE:
1. Does implementation match journey intent?
2. Are design principles followed?
3. Emotional arc achieved? (1-5)

VERDICT: PASS | NEEDS_WORK | FAIL
```
```

**Output:** `{project}/docs/design/tests/T-001-{name}.md`

---

## Phase 8.5: Test Validation

**Purpose:** Stress test the tests themselves.

**Run these checks:**

### Check 1: False Positive Detection

- Could any test pass even if feature is broken?
- Any tests that only check "no error"?
- Any assertions so weak they'd pass for wrong output?

**Pass criteria:** Rigorous assertions

### Check 2: False Negative Detection

- Any tests too strict about implementation details?
- Any timing-dependent tests that could flake?
- Any hardcoded values that might change?

**Pass criteria:** Stable, resilient tests

### Check 3: Spec Coverage

- Does every requirement have a test?
- Any orphan tests with no requirement?

**Pass criteria:** 100% requirement coverage

### Check 4: Mutation Survival

For each test, imagine:
- What if we returned null?
- What if we swapped < for >?
- What if we off-by-one'd a loop?

Would test catch it?

**Pass criteria:** Mutations would be caught

### Check 5: The Inversion Test

1. Deliberately break implementation
2. Run tests
3. Do they fail?
4. Do failure messages help diagnose?

**Pass criteria:** Tests fail when code breaks

**Validation loop:** Minimum 2 iterations

**Output:** `{project}/docs/design/tests/T-001-validation.md`

---

## Handoff to Zeroshot

When all phases complete:

```markdown
## Ready for Implementation

**Artifacts:**
- {N} specs in `{project}/docs/design/specs/`
- {N} tests in `{project}/docs/design/tests/`
- Tokens in `{project}/docs/design/tokens.md`

**Zeroshot command:**
```bash
zeroshot run --specs ./docs/design/specs --tests ./docs/design/tests
```

**Or Ralph:**
```bash
ralph build --spec ./docs/design/specs/S-001-*.md
```
```

---

## Phase 9: Retrospective

**Purpose:** Capture learnings after implementation.

**After implementation, analyze:**

### Research Accuracy
| Claim | Reality | Delta |
|-------|---------|-------|
| {what we researched} | {what happened} | {match/miss} |

### Journey Accuracy
| Step | Expected | Actual | Delta |
|------|----------|--------|-------|
| {step} | {designed} | {reality} | {match/miss} |

### Spec Accuracy
| Spec | Issues During Implementation |
|------|------------------------------|

### Test Accuracy
| Bug Found | Which Test Should Have Caught | Why It Didn't |
|-----------|-------------------------------|---------------|

### Learnings to Propagate

| Learning | Update To |
|----------|-----------|
| {insight} | PRINCIPLES.md / PATTERNS.md / Domains/ |

**Output:** `{project}/docs/design/retrospective.md`

---

## Escape Hatch

If complexity discovered mid-process:

```
 This seems more complex than {current-mode} assumes:
- {reason}
- {reason}

Recommend upgrading to {higher-mode}.

[Upgrade] [Continue] [Discuss]
```

---

## Quick Reference

## Template Locations

content.text:
Base directory for this skill: /Users/samuel.selvan/.claude/plugins/cache/claude-plugins-official/frontend-design/96276205880a/skills/frontend-design

This skill guides creation of distinctive, production-grade frontend interfaces that avoid generic "AI slop" aesthetics. Implement real working code with exceptional attention to aesthetic details and creative choices.

The user provides frontend requirements: a component, page, application, or interface to build. They may include context about the purpose, audience, or technical constraints.

## Design Thinking

Before coding, understand the context and commit to a BOLD aesthetic direction:
- **Purpose**: What problem does this interface solve? Who uses it?
- **Tone**: Pick an extreme: brutally minimal, maximalist chaos, retro-futuristic, organic/natural, luxury/refined, playful/toy-like, editorial/magazine, brutalist/raw, art deco/geometric, soft/pastel, industrial/utilitarian, etc. There are so many flavors to choose from. Use these for inspiration but design one that is true to the aesthetic direction.
- **Constraints**: Technical requirements (framework, performance, accessibility).
- **Differentiation**: What makes this UNFORGETTABLE? What's the one thing someone will remember?

**CRITICAL**: Choose a clear conceptual direction and execute it with precision. Bold maximalism and refined minimalism both work - the key is intentionality, not intensity.

Then implement working code (HTML/CSS/JS, React, Vue, etc.) that is:
- Production-grade and functional
- Visually striking and memorable
- Cohesive with a clear aesthetic point-of-view
- Meticulously refined in every detail

## Frontend Aesthetics Guidelines

Focus on:
- **Typography**: Choose fonts that are beautiful, unique, and interesting. Avoid generic fonts like Arial and Inter; opt instead for distinctive choices that elevate the frontend's aesthetics; unexpected, characterful font choices. Pair a distinctive display font with a refined body font.
- **Color & Theme**: Commit to a cohesive aesthetic. Use CSS variables for consistency. Dominant colors with sharp accents outperform timid, evenly-distributed palettes.
- **Motion**: Use animations for effects and micro-interactions. Prioritize CSS-only solutions for HTML. Use Motion library for React when available. Focus on high-impact moments: one well-orchestrated page load with staggered reveals (animation-delay) creates more delight than scattered micro-interactions. Use scroll-triggering and hover states that surprise.
- **Spatial Composition**: Unexpected layouts. Asymmetry. Overlap. Diagonal flow. Grid-breaking elements. Generous negative space OR controlled density.
- **Backgrounds & Visual Details**: Create atmosphere and depth rather than defaulting to solid colors. Add contextual effects and textures that match the overall aesthetic. Apply creative forms like gradient meshes, noise textures, geometric patterns, layered transparencies, dramatic shadows, decorative borders, custom cursors, and grain overlays.

NEVER use generic AI-generated aesthetics like overused font families (Inter, Roboto, Arial, system fonts), cliched color schemes (particularly purple gradients on white backgrounds), predictable layouts and component patterns, and cookie-cutter design that lacks context-specific character.

Interpret creatively and make unexpected choices that feel genuinely designed for the context. No design should be the same. Vary between light and dark themes, different fonts, different aesthetics. NEVER converge on common choices (Space Grotesk, for example) across generations.

**IMPORTANT**: Match implementation complexity to the aesthetic vision. Maximalist designs need elaborate code with extensive animations and effects. Minimalist or refined designs need restraint, precision, and careful attention to spacing, typography, and subtle details. Elegance comes from executing the vision well.

Remember: Claude is capable of extraordinary creative work. Don't hold back, show what can truly be created when thinking outside the box and committing fully to a distinctive vision.

2. **Retro Wellness** - 70s health food aesthetic, warm browns, organic shapes, vintage feel
3. **Japanese Minimalism** - Clean, purposeful, with careful negative space
4. **Neo-Brutalist Health** - High contrast, bold typography, raw but warm

For a calorie tracker, I think **Warm Organic/Wellness** could be distinctive without being jarring. Think: 
- Warm cream backgrounds instead of stark white
- Soft gradient overlays
- Rounded, organic shapes
- A distinctive serif or display font for headings
- Progress visualized as something more interesting than bars (radial, arc, organic shapes)

# Research: Calorie Tracker Redesign

id: R-001
date: 2026-01-17
domain: health/wellness/nutrition

## Domain Context

**Industry:** Personal health & nutrition tracking
**Users:** Health-conscious individuals tracking daily food intake
**Emotional Goal:** Calm confidence, gentle encouragement, sustainable habits (NOT guilt/anxiety)

## Domain Experts & Legends

| Expert | Known For | Key Insight |
|--------|-----------|-------------|
| Headspace | Wellness app design | Calming illustrations, soft motion, no guilt-inducing metrics |
| Oura Ring | Health tracking | Dark mode luxury, minimal data density, premium feel |
| Noom | Behavior change | Friendly coaching tone, celebrating small wins |
| Apple Health | Data visualization | Clean gradients, ring progress, clear hierarchy |
| Zero (fasting) | Fasting tracker | Elegant arc progress, dark/warm palette, meditative |

## Prior Art

### Direct Competitors

| Product | Strength | Weakness | Steal This |
|---------|----------|----------|------------|
| MyFitnessPal | Comprehensive database | Cluttered, ad-heavy, utilitarian | Search/quick-add patterns |
| Lose It! | Friendly tone | Generic mobile UI | Celebration moments |
| Cronometer | Data accuracy | Dense, clinical feel | Macro breakdown approach |
| Zero | Beautiful arc progress | Limited to fasting | Radial progress visualization |

### Adjacent Inspiration

| Source | Domain | Pattern | Apply How |
|--------|--------|---------|-----------|
| Headspace | Meditation | Soft blob gradients, breathing animations | Background atmosphere |
| Oura | Sleep tracking | Dark luxury, glowing accents | Evening/night mode |
| Stripe Dashboard | Fintech | Gradient backgrounds, glass cards | Progress card treatment |
| Linear | Productivity | Subtle gradients, refined type | Settings/form design |

### Anti-Patterns

| Source | Failure | Lesson |
|--------|---------|--------|
| MyFitnessPal | Red "over" states create anxiety | Use warm yellows, not alarm red |
| Generic trackers | Inter + teal = forgettable | Commit to distinctive typography |
| Fitness apps | Aggressive gamification | Gentle encouragement > punishment |

## Cross-Domain Inspiration

| Domain | Source | Insight |
|--------|--------|---------|
| Architecture | Tadao Ando | Light and shadow, concrete warmth, intentional negative space |
| Industrial Design | Jasper Morrison (super normal) | Warm materials, unfussy elegance |
| Art/Visual | Japanese ceramics (wabi-sabi) | Imperfection is beautiful, organic shapes |
| Print | Kinfolk magazine | Warm photography, generous whitespace, distinctive serif type |

## Aesthetic Direction: "Warm Wellness"

> [!important] Chosen Direction
> **Kinfolk meets Headspace**  Editorial sophistication with soft, calming atmosphere.
> Premium wellness magazine aesthetic, not clinical health app.

### Signature Elements

1. **Warm cream background** with subtle grain texture (not stark white)
2. **Radial/arc progress** instead of boring horizontal bars
3. **Distinctive serif display font** for headings (Fraunces, Newsreader, or Playfair)
4. **Soft gradient orbs** as background atmosphere
5. **Warm earth palette**  sage, terracotta, cream, espresso
6. **Generous negative space**  breathe, don't cram

### Emotional Arc

| State | Emotion | Design Response |
|-------|---------|-----------------|
| Empty day | Fresh start | Clean, inviting, easy entry point |
| Tracking | Engaged flow | Smooth animations, satisfying feedback |
| Near goal | Gentle excitement | Warm glow, subtle celebration |
| Over goal | No guilt | Amber (not red), tomorrow is new |
| Complete | Accomplished | Subtle confetti or glow, not aggressive |

## Token Recommendations

### Typography

- **Display:** Fraunces (variable, optical sizing, warm personality)
  - Why: Distinctive, warm, readable, free via Google Fonts
  - Alternative: Newsreader, Playfair Display
- **Body:** Nunito Sans or DM Sans (soft, friendly, readable)
  - Why: Pairs well with serif, doesn't compete

### Color

| Token | Value | Meaning |
|-------|-------|---------|
| background | #FAF7F2 | Warm cream paper |
| surface | #FFFFFF | Card/elevated surfaces |
| primary | #5C6B54 | Sage green (calm, growth) |
| accent | #C17B5F | Terracotta (warmth, nourishment) |
| success | #7D9B76 | Soft green (achievement) |
| warning | #D4A574 | Warm amber (gentle alert) |
| text | #3D3D3D | Espresso (warm black) |
| muted | #8B8B8B | Warm gray |
| protein | #8B7355 | Warm brown |
| carbs | #C4A35A | Golden amber |
| fat | #B08D7A | Dusty rose-brown |

### Principles Derived

1. **Warmth over clinical**  This is nourishment, not hospital
2. **Calm over urgent**  Sustainable habits > anxiety spikes
3. **Editorial over app**  Magazine-quality typography and spacing
4. **Radial over linear**  Progress as satisfying arcs, not bars
5. **Celebrate, don't punish**  "Over" is amber, not angry red

## Visual Concepts

### Progress Visualization (Hero Element)

```
     
                  
      1,847             Large radial progress ring
                     Thick arc shows calories
     of 2,000             Glowing when near goal
                  
     

   P   C   F 
      72g       180g      45g

    Mini arcs or pill bars for macros
```

### Card Treatment

- Subtle shadow with warm tint
- 1px border in cream/sage
- Generous padding (20-24px)
- Rounded corners (16-20px)

### Background Atmosphere

- Warm cream base (#FAF7F2)
- Large soft gradient orb (sage  terracotta, very low opacity)
- Subtle noise/grain texture overlay
- No harsh lines or stark contrasts

input.content:
# Constraints: Calorie Tracker Redesign

id: C-001
date: 2026-01-17

## Technical Boundaries

### Stack (Fixed)
- **Framework:** Preact + Vite (keep  lightweight, fast)
- **Styling:** CSS with custom properties (keep  no build deps)
- **Storage:** IndexedDB + localStorage (keep  local-first)
- **Deployment:** GitHub Pages (keep  free, static)

### No New Dependencies
- Must work with vanilla CSS (no Tailwind, no CSS-in-JS)
- Animations via CSS only (no Framer Motion, no GSAP)
- Fonts via Google Fonts CDN

### Browser Support
- Modern browsers only (Chrome, Safari, Firefox, Edge)
- No IE11, no legacy

## Performance Budgets

| Metric | Target | Current |
|--------|--------|---------|
| First paint | <1s | Good |
| Bundle size | <100KB | Good |
| CSS size | <20KB | ~10KB |
| Animation FPS | 60fps | N/A |

## Resource Reality

- **Timeline:** Single session redesign
- **Scope:** Visual refresh, not feature addition
- **Risk tolerance:** Medium (can break current look)

## Non-Negotiables

1. **Mobile-first**  Must work at 320px, optimized for 480px
2. **Accessibility**  Color contrast 4.5:1, keyboard nav, focus states
3. **Local-first**  No external API calls for core function
4. **Existing functionality**  All current features must work

## Explicit Descopes

| Descoped | Reason |
|----------|--------|
| Dark mode | Future feature, not this session |
| Component library | Overkill for single app |
| Design system docs | Just need working code |
| Animation library | CSS transitions sufficient |
| New features | Visual refresh only |

## Files to Modify

### Primary (will change)
- `src/styles.css`  Complete overhaul
- `src/components/DailyProgress.jsx`  New radial progress
- `index.html`  Add Google Fonts

### Secondary (may change)
- `src/components/Header.jsx`  Typography refresh
- `src/components/EntryForm.jsx`  Form styling
- `src/components/EntryList.jsx`  Card treatment

### Untouched
- `src/utils/*`  Business logic unchanged
- `src/components/App.jsx`  Structure unchanged

content.text:
Base directory for this skill: /Users/samuel.selvan/.claude/plugins/cache/superpowers-marketplace/superpowers/4.0.3/skills/brainstorming

# Brainstorming Ideas Into Designs

## Overview

Help turn ideas into fully formed designs and specs through natural collaborative dialogue.

Start by understanding the current project context, then ask questions one at a time to refine the idea. Once you understand what you're building, present the design in small sections (200-300 words), checking after each section whether it looks right so far.

## The Process

**Understanding the idea:**
- Check out the current project state first (files, docs, recent commits)
- Ask questions one at a time to refine the idea
- Prefer multiple choice questions when possible, but open-ended is fine too
- Only one question per message - if a topic needs more exploration, break it into multiple questions
- Focus on understanding: purpose, constraints, success criteria

**Exploring approaches:**
- Propose 2-3 different approaches with trade-offs
- Present options conversationally with your recommendation and reasoning
- Lead with your recommended option and explain why

**Presenting the design:**
- Once you believe you understand what you're building, present the design
- Break it into sections of 200-300 words
- Ask after each section whether it looks right so far
- Cover: architecture, components, data flow, error handling, testing
- Be ready to go back and clarify if something doesn't make sense

## After the Design

**Documentation:**
- Write the validated design to `docs/plans/YYYY-MM-DD-<topic>-design.md`
- Use elements-of-style:writing-clearly-and-concisely skill if available
- Commit the design document to git

**Implementation (if continuing):**
- Ask: "Ready to set up for implementation?"
- Use superpowers:using-git-worktrees to create isolated workspace
- Use superpowers:writing-plans to create detailed implementation plan

## Key Principles

- **One question at a time** - Don't overwhelm with multiple questions
- **Multiple choice preferred** - Easier to answer than open-ended when possible
- **YAGNI ruthlessly** - Remove unnecessary features from all designs
- **Explore alternatives** - Always propose 2-3 approaches before settling
- **Incremental validation** - Present design in sections, validate each
- **Be flexible** - Go back and clarify when something doesn't make sense

## The Inspiration Theft Map

### From Headspace (meditation app)

### From Zero (fasting app)

- **Streak tracking**  Visual chain of successful days
- **Dark mode luxury**  Evening/night shifts to calming dark theme

### From Oura Ring

- **Minimal data density**  Show less, mean more
- **Readiness concept**  "You have 847 cal budget remaining" feels different than raw numbers

### From Japanese Wabi-Sabi / Ma
- **Intentional emptiness**  Zen empty states that feel peaceful, not broken
- **Organic shapes**  Imperfect circles, hand-drawn feel
- **Seasonal awareness**  Subtle seasonal color shifts?

### From Tadao Ando (architect)
- **Time-of-day light**  Morning warmth  midday clarity  evening calm
- **Shadow play**  Depth through light, not just drop shadows
- **Material honesty**  The interface should feel "real"

### From Dieter Rams
- **Less but better**  Cut features that don't earn their place
- **Timeless over trendy**  Avoid "2024 design trends"

---

Does this inspiration map resonate? Anything missing you'd want to steal from?

content.thinking:
The user is asking about more artists they could draw inspiration from - they mentioned Rothko (Mark Rothko, abstract expressionist known for color field paintings) and Kelly (likely Ellsworth Kelly, known for hard-edge painting and bold color shapes).

This is a great question - let me think about artists whose work could inform a calorie tracking app's visual design:

**Color Field / Abstract Expressionists:**
- Mark Rothko - Luminous color blocks, emotional resonance through color alone, soft edges, meditative quality
- Ellsworth Kelly - Bold shapes, high contrast, clean edges, color as form
- Josef Albers - Color interaction, nested squares, how colors affect each other
- Helen Frankenthaler - Stained color, organic flow, watercolor-like transparency
- Agnes Martin - Grids, subtle lines, meditative minimalism, pale colors

**Minimalists:**
- Donald Judd - Clean geometric forms, industrial materials, repetition
- Dan Flavin - Light as medium, color through illumination
- James Turrell - Light installations, perception, atmospheric color

**Japanese Artists:**
- Yayoi Kusama - Dots, infinity, repetition (could be interesting for data viz)
- Hiroshi Sugimoto - Seascapes, gradients, time, long exposure

**Contemporary / Digital-adjacent:**
- Olafur Eliasson - Light, color, perception, immersive environments
- James Turrell - Sky spaces, color perception
- Gerhard Richter - Color charts, blurred photography

**Graphic Design / Visual:**
- Josef Mller-Brockmann - Swiss grid, typography, clean layouts
- Paul Rand - Playful modernism, bold shapes
- Saul Bass - Motion, title sequences, kinetic type

**For this calorie tracker specifically, I'd recommend:**

1. **Rothko** - His color fields could inspire the background atmosphere - layered, luminous colors that breathe


2. **Agnes Martin's** subtle grids and restrained palette could shape a more contemplative interface. **Turrell's** work with light and perception might inform how time-based theming shifts throughout the day. **Albers' color theory** could guide how the macronutrient colors (protein, carbs, fat) interact and balance visually. **Eliasson's** immersive light environments could inspire celebratory moments or achievement states within the app.

content.text:
Yes! Let me expand the artist inspiration map with direct applications:

---

## Artists  App Applications

### Color Field / Abstract Expressionists

| Artist | Known For | Steal This |
|--------|-----------|------------|
| **Mark Rothko** | Luminous stacked color blocks, soft edges, emotional resonance | Background atmosphere  layered color fields that *glow* from within, not flat gradients |
| **Ellsworth Kelly** | Bold color shapes, hard edges, color as form | Macro visualization  protein/carbs/fat as bold overlapping shapes instead of rings |
| **Josef Albers** | Color interaction ("Interaction of Color") | How our 3 macro colors sit next to each other  they should harmonize, not fight |
| **Helen Frankenthaler** | Stained canvas, organic flow, transparency | Watercolor-like progress fills, bleeds at edges, not hard stops |
| **Agnes Martin** | Subtle grids, pale palette, meditative minimalism | Calming grid-based layouts, very pale backgrounds, zen stillness |

### Light Artists

| Artist | Known For | Steal This |
|--------|-----------|------------|
| **James Turrell** | Skyspaces, perception of light, atmospheric color | Time-of-day theming  not just "light/dark mode" but *perceptual shifts* in how colors feel |
| **Dan Flavin** | Fluorescent light installations, color through glow | UI elements that emit light  progress rings that genuinely *glow*, not just have drop shadows |
| **Olafur Eliasson** | Immersive environments, weather, perception | Celebration states  when you hit your goal, the whole screen shifts atmosphere |

### Minimalists / Grid Masters

| Artist | Known For | Steal This |
|--------|-----------|------------|
| **Donald Judd** | Precise boxes, industrial warmth, repetition | Entry cards as beautiful repeated units, mathematical spacing |
| **Sol LeWitt** | Instruction-based art, systematic variations | Data visualization through simple rules, generative patterns |

### Japanese Influence

| Artist | Known For | Steal This |
|--------|-----------|------------|
| **Hiroshi Sugimoto** | Seascape gradients, time passing, stillness | Progress as horizon line, gradient backgrounds that feel like sky/sea |
| **Yayoi Kusama** | Infinity dots, repetition, immersion | Celebration confetti? Dot patterns for texture? |

### Motion / Kinetic

| Artist | Known For | Steal This |
|--------|-----------|------------|
| **Bridget Riley** | Op art, visual vibration, movement through pattern | Subtle movement in static elements, visual rhythm |
| **Alexander Calder** | Mobiles, balanced movement, playfulness | UI elements that feel like they have *weight* and *balance* |

---

## My Top Picks for This App

If I had to choose 4 to deeply influence this redesign:

1. **Rothko**  Background atmosphere (luminous color fields)
2. **Turrell**  Time-of-day perception shifts
3. **Agnes Martin**  Meditative calm, pale palette, grid rhythm
4. **Frankenthaler**  Organic, soft progress fills (not hard-edged)

---

Does this open up directions you want to explore? Any of these calling to you more than others?

content.text:
Quick visual primer on your new influences:

---

## Agnes Martin (19122004)

**The vibe:** Meditative minimalism. Pale, almost-white canvases with subtle pencil grids. Looking at her work feels like staring at morning fog or hearing silence.

**What we steal:**
- Extremely pale backgrounds (not stark white, not obviously colored  *barely there*)
- Subtle grid rhythms in spacing
- Stillness  the UI should feel quiet, not busy
- Imperfection in perfection  her hand-drawn lines wobble slightly

**Google:** "Agnes Martin paintings"  look for the pale pink/blue grids

---

## Helen Frankenthaler (19282011)

**The vibe:** She poured thinned paint onto raw canvas, letting it soak and bleed. Organic shapes, watercolor-like transparency, colors that flow into each other.

**What we steal:**
- Progress fills that *bleed* at edges, not hard stops
- Colors that feel like they're soaking into the surface
- Organic, imperfect shapes (not pixel-perfect circles)
- Layered transparency  colors showing through each other

**Google:** "Helen Frankenthaler Mountains and Sea"  that's the breakthrough piece

---

## The Turrell Connection

You already love Turrell  his Skyspaces and Ganzfeld works are about **perception shifting**. Light that makes you unsure where the wall ends. Color that changes how you *feel*, not just what you *see*.

For this app: the interface should shift with time of day in a way that feels **perceptual**, not just "dark mode toggle."

---

Now  ready for me to propose the phased roadmap for this multi-session overhaul?

content.thinking: Let me present the phased roadmap now.

content.text:
## Phased Roadmap: Calorie Tracker Experience Overhaul

---

### Phase 1: Atmosphere & Perception
**Artists:** Rothko, Turrell, Agnes Martin

| Feature | Description |
|---------|-------------|
| Time-of-day theming | Morning (warm cream/peach)  Midday (clear/bright)  Evening (cool sage)  Night (dark mode) |
| Rothko backgrounds | Layered, luminous color fields that glow from within  not flat gradients |
| Agnes Martin spacing | Mathematical grid rhythm, generous whitespace, quiet stillness |
| Turrell transitions | Colors shift gradually over hours, not jarring mode switches |

**Deliverable:** The app *feels* different at 7am vs 7pm

---

### Phase 2: Organic Motion
**Artists:** Frankenthaler, Calder

| Feature | Description |
|---------|-------------|
| Soft progress fills | Edges that bleed/feather like watercolor, not hard stops |
| Floating FAB | Subtle idle bob, like a Calder mobile in gentle breeze |
| Staggered entry animations | Cards fade in with slight delays, settling into place |
| Number animations | Calories count up smoothly, not instant jumps |
| Balanced micro-motion | Buttons that have weight, elements that settle |

**Deliverable:** Everything feels alive but calm  breathing, not buzzing

---

### Phase 3: Celebration & Streaks
**Artists:** Kusama, Calder

| Feature | Description |
|---------|-------------|
| Goal-hit celebration | Kusama dots multiply across screen, then drift away like Calder mobile |
| Streak visualization | Dots extending into "infinity"  your chain of successful days |
| Milestone moments | 7-day, 30-day, 100-day celebrations with increasing intensity |
| Gentle coaching | "You're doing great" messages, Headspace tone |

**Deliverable:** Hitting your goal feels *magical*, not just "100% complete"

---

### Phase 4: Daily Experience Features

| Feature | Description |
|---------|-------------|
| Meal categories | Breakfast / Lunch / Dinner / Snacks  collapsible sections |
| Quick-add favorites | Star foods, one-tap to add again |
| Recent foods | Last 10 items, instant re-add |
| Meal templates | "My usual breakfast" = 3 items added at once |

**Deliverable:** Logging takes 5 seconds, not 30

---

### Phase 5: Progress & Motivation

| Feature | Description |
|---------|-------------|
| Streak tracking | Visual dot chain (Kusama), streak freeze option |
| Weekly trends | This week vs last week, Sugimoto horizon-style gradient |
| Insights | "You tend to overeat on Fridays"  gentle, not judgmental |
| Share achievements | Export milestone cards for social |

**Deliverable:** Long-term motivation, not just daily logging

---

### Phase 6: Polish & PWA

| Feature | Description |
|---------|-------------|
| Dark mode | Turrell-inspired night perception, not just inverted colors |
| Offline / PWA | Service worker, install prompt, works without internet |
| Notifications | Gentle meal reminders (opt-in) |
| Accessibility audit | Screen reader, keyboard nav, reduced motion |

FROM node:20

ARG TZ
ENV TZ="$TZ"

ARG CLAUDE_CODE_VERSION=latest

# Install basic development tools and Python
RUN apt-get update && apt-get install -y --no-install-recommends \
  less \
  git \
  procps \
  sudo \
  fzf \
  zsh \
  man-db \
  unzip \
  gnupg2 \
  gh \
  jq \
  nano \
  vim \
  python3 \
  python3-pip \
  python3-venv \
  && apt-get clean && rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/*

# Create python symlink
RUN ln -sf /usr/bin/python3 /usr/local/bin/python

# Ensure default node user has access to /usr/local/share
RUN mkdir -p /usr/local/share/npm-global && \
  chown -R node:node /usr/local/share

ARG USERNAME=node

# Persist bash history
RUN mkdir /commandhistory && \
  touch /commandhistory/.bash_history && \
  chown -R $USERNAME /commandhistory

# Set environment variables
ENV DEVCONTAINER=true

# Create workspace and config directories
RUN mkdir -p /workspace /home/node/.claude && \
  chown -R node:node /workspace /home/node/.claude

WORKDIR /workspace

ARG GIT_DELTA_VERSION=0.18.2
RUN ARCH=$(dpkg --print-architecture) && \
  wget "https://github.com/dandavison/delta/releases/download/${GIT_DELTA_VERSION}/git-delta_${GIT_DELTA_VERSION}_${ARCH}.deb" && \
  dpkg -i "git-delta_${GIT_DELTA_VERSION}_${ARCH}.deb" && \
  rm "git-delta_${GIT_DELTA_VERSION}_${ARCH}.deb"

# Set up non-root user
USER node

# Install global packages
ENV NPM_CONFIG_PREFIX=/usr/local/share/npm-global
ENV PATH=$PATH:/usr/local/share/npm-global/bin:/home/node/.local/bin

# Shell config
ENV SHELL=/bin/zsh
ENV EDITOR=nano
ENV VISUAL=nano

# Install zsh with plugins
ARG ZSH_IN_DOCKER_VERSION=1.2.0
RUN sh -c "$(wget -O- https://github.com/deluan/zsh-in-docker/releases/download/v${ZSH_IN_DOCKER_VERSION}/zsh-in-docker.sh)" -- \
  -p git \
  -p fzf \
  -a "source /usr/share/doc/fzf/examples/key-bindings.zsh 2>/dev/null || true" \
  -a "source /usr/share/doc/fzf/examples/completion.zsh 2>/dev/null || true" \
  -a "export HISTFILE=/commandhistory/.bash_history" \
  -x

# Install Claude Code and zeroshot
RUN npm install -g @anthropic-ai/claude-code@${CLAUDE_CODE_VERSION} @covibes/zeroshot

input.content:
# Calorie Tracker Experience Overhaul

**Date:** 2026-01-17
**Status:** Approved
**Approach:** Multi-session, spec-per-feature, Zeroshot execution

---

## Vision

Transform a functional calorie tracker into a **distinctive, emotionally resonant experience** by stealing aggressively from fine artists, architects, and best-in-class wellness apps.

**Target feeling:** The app should feel like a calm, supportive companion  not a judgmental scoreboard.

---

## Artistic Influences

| Artist | Era | Known For | Application |
|--------|-----|-----------|-------------|
| Mark Rothko | Abstract Expressionism | Luminous color fields, emotional resonance | Background atmosphere  colors that glow from within |
| James Turrell | Light Art | Skyspaces, perceptual shifts, light as medium | Time-of-day theming  perception changes, not just color swaps |
| Agnes Martin | Minimalism | Pale grids, meditative stillness, quiet | Spacing rhythm, pale palette, intentional emptiness |
| Helen Frankenthaler | Color Field | Stained canvas, organic bleeds, watercolor feel | Progress fills with soft edges, not hard stops |
| Alexander Calder | Kinetic Art | Mobiles, balance, playful movement | Floating micro-motion, elements that settle with weight |
| Yayoi Kusama | Contemporary | Infinity dots, obsessive repetition, immersion | Celebration states, streak visualization |

## App Influences

| App | Steal This |
|-----|------------|
| Headspace | Breathing animations, celebration moments, coaching tone |
| Zero | Elegant arc progress, dark mode luxury, meditative feel |
| Oura Ring | Weekly trends, minimal data density, premium feel |
| Apple Health | Ring progress, clean gradients |

## Cross-Domain Influences

| Domain | Source | Steal This |
|--------|--------|------------|
| Japanese aesthetics | Wabi-sabi, Ma | Intentional emptiness, imperfection as beauty |
| Architecture | Tadao Ando | Light/shadow play, time-of-day awareness |
| Industrial Design | Dieter Rams | Less but better, timeless over trendy |

---

## Phase Breakdown

### Phase 1: Atmosphere & Perception
**Artists:** Rothko, Turrell, Agnes Martin

| Spec | Feature |
|------|---------|
| `01-time-of-day-theming` | Gradual color shifts: morning warmth  midday clarity  evening calm  night dark |
| `02-rothko-backgrounds` | Layered, luminous color fields that glow from within |
| `03-agnes-martin-spacing` | Mathematical grid rhythm, generous whitespace, quiet stillness |

### Phase 2: Organic Motion
**Artists:** Frankenthaler, Calder

| Spec | Feature |
|------|---------|
| `04-frankenthaler-progress` | Soft-edge progress fills that bleed like watercolor |
| `05-calder-floating-motion` | Floating FAB, elements that bob and settle |
| `06-staggered-animations` | Entry cards fade in with delays, numbers count up |

### Phase 3: Celebration & Streaks
**Artists:** Kusama, Calder

| Spec | Feature |
|------|---------|
| `07-kusama-celebration` | Goal-hit triggers multiplying dots across screen |
| `08-streak-visualization` | Dots extending into infinity  chain of successful days |
| `09-milestone-moments` | 7-day, 30-day, 100-day celebrations |
| `10-coaching-messages` | Gentle Headspace-style encouragement |

### Phase 4: Daily Experience Features

| Spec | Feature |
|------|---------|
| `11-meal-categories` | Breakfast / Lunch / Dinner / Snacks sections |
| `12-quick-add-favorites` | Star foods, one-tap re-add |
| `13-recent-foods` | Last 10 items, instant re-add |
| `14-meal-templates` | "My usual breakfast" = multiple items at once |

### Phase 5: Progress & Motivation

| Spec | Feature |
|------|---------|
| `15-streak-tracking` | Visual dot chain, streak freeze option |
| `16-weekly-trends` | This week vs last week comparison |
| `17-insights` | "You tend to overeat on Fridays" |
| `18-share-achievements` | Export milestone cards |

### Phase 6: Polish & PWA

| Spec | Feature |
|------|---------|
| `19-dark-mode` | Turrell-inspired night perception |
| `20-pwa-offline` | Service worker, install prompt |
| `21-notifications` | Gentle meal reminders |
| `22-accessibility` | Screen reader, keyboard nav, reduced motion |

---

## Technical Constraints

- **Framework:** Preact + Vite (keep)
- **Styling:** CSS with custom properties (no Tailwind)
- **Animations:** CSS only (no JS animation libraries)
- **Storage:** IndexedDB + localStorage (local-first)
- **Deployment:** GitHub Pages

---

## Design Tokens (Current)

See `docs/design/tokens.md` for full token system.

**Palette:** Warm Wellness (sage, terracotta, cream)
**Typography:** Fraunces (display) + Nunito Sans (body)

---

## Success Criteria

1. **Distinctive:** Someone seeing a screenshot knows it's not a generic app
2. **Calm:** Using it feels peaceful, not stressful
3. **Delightful:** Hitting goals feels celebratory
4. **Fast:** Logging takes <10 seconds
5. **Sustainable:** Encourages long-term habits, not short-term guilt

---

## Zeroshot Execution

```bash
# Run individual specs
zeroshot run specs/01-time-of-day-theming.md

# Run all Phase 1 specs
zeroshot run specs/0[1-3]-*.md

# Run full overhaul
zeroshot run specs/
```

---

## Session Plan

| Session | Specs | Focus |
|---------|-------|-------|
| 1 | 01-03 | Atmosphere & time-of-day |
| 2 | 04-06 | Motion & organic fills |
| 3 | 07-10 | Celebrations & streaks |
| 4 | 11-14 | Daily experience features |
| 5 | 15-18 | Progress & motivation |
| 6 | 19-22 | Polish & PWA |

input.content:
# Spec: Time-of-Day Theming

**Phase:** 1 - Atmosphere & Perception
**Artist Influence:** James Turrell (Skyspaces, perceptual light shifts)
**Priority:** High
**Estimated Effort:** Medium

---

## Overview

Implement a time-of-day theming system inspired by James Turrell's light installations. The app should gradually shift its color perception throughout the day  not jarring mode switches, but subtle perceptual transitions that make morning feel warm and evening feel calm.

## Artist Context

James Turrell creates "Skyspaces"  rooms with apertures to the sky where viewers experience light changing over time. The key insight: **light affects how we feel**, not just what we see. Our app should embody this  the 7am experience should *feel* different from 7pm.

## Requirements

### Time Periods

| Period | Hours | Emotional Goal | Color Shift |
|--------|-------|----------------|-------------|
| Morning | 5am - 11am | Warm, energizing, fresh start | Warmer creams, peachy undertones |
| Midday | 11am - 4pm | Clear, focused, productive | Neutral, current palette |
| Evening | 4pm - 8pm | Calm, winding down | Cooler sage, softer contrast |
| Night | 8pm - 5am | Restful, low stimulation | Dark mode, muted colors |

### Implementation

1. **CSS Custom Properties:** All colors must use CSS variables that can be swapped
2. **Smooth Transitions:** Colors transition over ~30 minutes, not instant switches
3. **JavaScript Time Detection:** Check system time, apply appropriate theme class
4. **No User Toggle (yet):** Automatic only  manual override is Phase 6

### CSS Variables to Create

```css
/* Morning overrides */
.theme-morning {
  --color-cream: #FDF8F3;      /* Warmer */
  --color-sage: #6B7A62;       /* Slightly warmer green */
  --color-terracotta: #D4896B; /* More peachy */
}

/* Evening overrides */
.theme-evening {
  --color-cream: #F5F5F0;      /* Cooler */
  --color-sage: #5A6B58;       /* Cooler green */
  --color-terracotta: #B8776A; /* Muted coral */
}

/* Night overrides */
.theme-night {
  --color-cream: #1A1A1A;      /* Dark background */
  --color-white: #242424;      /* Dark surface */
  --color-sage: #8A9A82;       /* Lighter for contrast */
  --color-espresso: #E8E8E8;   /* Light text */
  /* ... full dark mode palette */
}
```

### JavaScript Logic

```javascript
// src/utils/theme.js
export function getTimeOfDay() {
  const hour = new Date().getHours()
  if (hour >= 5 && hour < 11) return 'morning'
  if (hour >= 11 && hour < 16) return 'midday'
  if (hour >= 16 && hour < 20) return 'evening'
  return 'night'
}

export function applyTheme() {
  const period = getTimeOfDay()
  document.body.className = `theme-${period}`
}

// Call on app load and every 15 minutes
```

### App.jsx Integration

```javascript
import { useEffect } from 'preact/hooks'
import { applyTheme } from '../utils/theme'

export function App() {
  useEffect(() => {
    applyTheme()
    const interval = setInterval(applyTheme, 15 * 60 * 1000) // Check every 15min
    return () => clearInterval(interval)
  }, [])

  // ... rest of component
}
```

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] App detects current time and applies appropriate theme class
- [ ] Morning (5-11am) has warmer, peachy undertones
- [ ] Midday (11am-4pm) uses default palette
- [ ] Evening (4-8pm) has cooler, calmer tones
- [ ] Night (8pm-5am) activates full dark mode
- [ ] Theme checks every 15 minutes for gradual transitions
- [ ] All existing UI elements work correctly in all themes
- [ ] Contrast ratios maintain accessibility (4.5:1 minimum)

## Files to Modify

- `src/styles.css`  Add theme variant classes
- `src/utils/theme.js`  Create (new file)
- `src/components/App.jsx`  Add theme effect

## Test Plan

1. Manually set system time to 7am  verify morning theme
2. Set time to 2pm  verify midday theme
3. Set time to 6pm  verify evening theme
4. Set time to 10pm  verify night theme
5. Run Lighthouse accessibility check on all themes

## Notes

- Night mode is critical for family use (checking before bed)
- Turrell's work emphasizes gradual perception shifts  avoid jarring changes
- Future: Add sunrise/sunset API for location-aware timing

# Spec: Gentle Coaching Messages **Phase:** 3 - Celebration & Streaks **Artist Influence:** Headspace (gentle, supportive tone) **Priority:** Low **Estimated Effort:** Low --- ## Overview Add contextual, **Headspace-style coaching messages** that encourage without judging. Messages should feel like a supportive friend, not a drill sergeant. ## Requirements ### Message Types ```javascript const MESSAGES = { morning_empty: [ "Good morning! Ready to fuel your day?", "A new day, a fresh start.", "What's for breakfast?", ], progress_good: [ "You're doing great!", "Nice and steady.", "On track for the day.", ], near_goal: [ "Almost there!", "Looking good!", "Just a little more room.", ], goal_reached: [ "You did it!", "Goal reached. Well done.", "Perfect day!", ], over_goal: [ "A little over today. That's okay.", "Tomorrow's a new day.", "One day doesn't define you.", ], streak_encouragement: [ "Keep the streak alive!", "{n} days strong!", "Consistency is key.", ], } ``` ### Message Selection Logic ```javascript export function getMessage(context) { const { totals, goals, timeOfDay, streak, hasEntries } = context const ratio = totals.calories / goals.calories if (!hasEntries && timeOfDay === 'morning') { return pickRandom(MESSAGES.morning_empty) } if (ratio >= 1.1) return pickRandom(MESSAGES.over_goal) if (ratio >= 1.0) return pickRandom(MESSAGES.goal_reached) if (ratio >= 0.85) return pickRandom(MESSAGES.near_goal) if (ratio >= 0.3) return pickRandom(MESSAGES.progress_good) return null // No message needed } ``` ### Display Component ```jsx function CoachingMessage({ message }) { if (!message) return null return (

{message}

) } ``` ### CSS ```css .coaching-message { text-align: center; padding: var(--space-3) var(--space-4); color: var(--color-warm-gray); font-size: 0.9375rem; font-style: italic; } .coaching-message p { margin: 0; } ``` ### Placement Below progress card, above entry list: ```jsx ``` ## Acceptance Criteria - [ ] Messages appear based on context - [ ] Tone is encouraging, never shaming - [ ] "Over goal" messages are gentle - [ ] Messages rotate (not same one always) - [ ] Can be disabled in settings (future) ## Files to Create/Modify - `src/utils/messages.js` Create - `src/components/CoachingMessage.jsx` Create - `src/components/App.jsx` Integration ## Tone Guidelines **DO:** - "You're doing great!" - "Tomorrow's a new day." - "Nice and steady." **DON'T:** - "You ate too much!" - "You failed today." - "Try harder tomorrow."

**Phase 2  Organic Motion (Frankenthaler/Calder)**

- `05-calder-floating-motion.md`  Weighted mobile-like motion

**Phase 3  Celebration & Streaks (Kusama/Headspace)**

**Phase 4  Smart Entry**

- `13-recent-foods.md`  Autocomplete from history

**Phase 5  Gamification & Insights**
- `15-streak-tracking-logic.md`  Core streak calculation
- `16-weekly-trends.md`  Agnes Martin-style bar charts
- `17-smart-insights.md`  Pattern recognition engine
- `18-share-achievements.md`  Shareable milestone cards

**Phase 6  Polish & Accessibility**
- `19-dark-mode.md`  Rothko-inspired dark theme
- `20-pwa-offline.md`  Installable offline-first app
- `21-notifications.md`  Gentle meal reminders
- `22-accessibility.md`  WCAG 2.1 AA compliance

You can now launch your devcontainer and run Zeroshot against these specs. Each spec is self-contained with data models, component code, CSS, acceptance criteria, and test plans.

The user wants prompts they can use with Zeroshot to implement each spec. Zeroshot typically takes a spec file and generates implementation. I should provide clear, copy-pasteable prompts for each spec that can be fed to Zeroshot.

Let me create prompts that:
1. Reference the spec file
2. Give clear implementation instructions
3. Are organized by phase for easy sequential execution

content.text:
Here are copy-pasteable Zeroshot prompts for each spec:

---

## Phase 1  Foundation

```
Implement spec: specs/01-time-of-day-theming.md

Create time-of-day theming with CSS custom properties that shift based on hour. 
Add getTimeOfDay() utility, update :root variables, integrate with App.jsx.
No external dependencies.
```

```
Implement spec: specs/02-rothko-backgrounds.md

Add Rothko-inspired gradient backgrounds to progress card and header.
Create CSS gradients with soft color transitions. Apply to existing components.
CSS only, no new components.
```

```
Implement spec: specs/03-agnes-martin-spacing.md

Implement 8px grid spacing system with CSS custom properties.
Update all spacing to use --space-N tokens. Add subtle grid pattern overlay.
Audit and update existing components for consistent rhythm.
```

---

## Phase 2  Organic Motion

```
Implement spec: specs/04-frankenthaler-progress.md

Enhance progress rings with soft-edge fills using SVG filters and gradients.
Add feGaussianBlur filter, gradient definitions, watercolor-style edges.
Modify DailyProgress.jsx and styles.css.
```

```
Implement spec: specs/05-calder-floating-motion.md

Add Calder-inspired floating animations to header elements and FAB.
Implement gentle bobbing motion with CSS keyframes and cubic-bezier easing.
Respect prefers-reduced-motion.
```

```
Implement spec: specs/06-staggered-animations.md

Create useAnimatedNumber hook for smooth number counting.
Add staggered entry-settle animation to entry cards with nth-child delays.
Integrate animated numbers into DailyProgress.jsx.
```

---

## Phase 3  Celebration & Streaks

```
Implement spec: specs/07-kusama-celebration.md

Create Celebration.jsx component with Kusama-inspired infinity dots.
40+ dots with random positions, staggered pop animation, 3-phase lifecycle.
Trigger on first goal completion per day. Store celebrated state in localStorage.
```

```
Implement spec: specs/08-streak-visualization.md

Create StreakDisplay.jsx component showing dots that fade into distance.
Add streak storage functions to storage.js (getStreakData, updateStreak).
Display max 14 dots with opacity/scale perspective effect.
```

```
Implement spec: specs/09-milestone-moments.md

Add milestone detection for 7/14/30/60/100 day streaks.
Create checkMilestone() function, trigger escalating celebrations.
Reuse Celebration component with intensity variants (small/medium/large/epic).
```

```
Implement spec: specs/10-coaching-messages.md

Create CoachingMessage.jsx and messages.js utility.
Implement getMessage() with context-aware selection (time, progress, streak).
Display below progress card. Gentle, Headspace-style tone.
```

---

## Phase 4  Smart Entry

```
Implement spec: specs/11-meal-categories.md

Add mealType field to entries (breakfast/lunch/dinner/snack).
Create meal type selector in EntryForm with time-based suggestions.
Group entries by meal type in EntryList with subtotals per group.
```

```
Implement spec: specs/12-quick-add-favorites.md

Create QuickAddBar.jsx for favorite foods as horizontal scrolling chips.
Add favorite storage functions. Show "save as favorite" prompt after entry.
Create FavoritesModal for management. Track usage count per favorite.
```

```
Implement spec: specs/13-recent-foods.md

Create FoodAutocomplete.jsx with dropdown suggestions from entry history.
Add recents.js utility for getRecentFoods and searchRecentFoods.
Keyboard navigation (arrow keys, enter, escape). Fill all fields on select.
```

```
Implement spec: specs/14-meal-templates.md

Create meal templates (combos) system for logging multiple foods at once.
Add templates.js storage, TemplateCard.jsx, CreateTemplateModal.jsx.
"Add All" creates individual entries for each item in template.
```

---

## Phase 5  Gamification & Insights

```
Implement spec: specs/15-streak-tracking-logic.md

Implement comprehensive streak tracking with 90-110% goal range.
Create streaks.js with all edge case handling (missed days, timezone).
Add recalculateStreak for data recovery. Integrate with App.jsx on load.
```

```
Implement spec: specs/16-weekly-trends.md

Create WeeklyChart.jsx with Agnes Martin-inspired minimal bar charts.
Add trends.js for getWeeklyTrends aggregation (4 weeks).
Show 7 bars per week, goal line, on-target highlighting. Metric switcher.
```

```
Implement spec: specs/17-smart-insights.md

Create insights.js engine generating personalized observations.
Pattern detection, achievement tracking, week-over-week comparisons.
InsightsPanel.jsx shows top 3 prioritized insights. Dismissible with persistence.
```

```
Implement spec: specs/18-share-achievements.md

Create ShareCard.jsx and ShareModal.jsx for shareable achievements.
Support Web Share API, copy text, download as PNG (html2canvas).
Branded card design with Kusama dots decoration. Add html2canvas dependency.
```

---

## Phase 6  Polish & Accessibility

```
Implement spec: specs/19-dark-mode.md

Implement dark mode with Rothko-inspired warm darks (not pure black).
Create theme.js with getThemePreference, setTheme, toggleTheme.
Add ThemeToggle.jsx, settings integration, system preference detection.
```

```
Implement spec: specs/20-pwa-offline.md

Convert app to PWA with full offline support.
Add manifest.json, service worker, VitePWA plugin configuration.
Create InstallPrompt.jsx, OfflineIndicator.jsx, UpdateToast.jsx.
Generate app icons (192px, 512px).
```

```
Implement spec: specs/21-notifications.md

Implement optional meal reminder notifications.
Create notifications.js for permission handling and scheduling.
NotificationSettings.jsx with per-meal time pickers.
Service worker notification handling with action buttons.
```

```
Implement spec: specs/22-accessibility.md

Comprehensive accessibility audit and fixes.
Add focus-trap.js, LiveRegion.jsx, SkipLinks.jsx.
ARIA labels on all interactive elements, keyboard shortcuts, reduced motion.
Verify WCAG AA contrast ratios throughout.
```

---

## Recommended Execution Order

Run specs in numerical order (01  22). Each phase builds on the previous. If you want parallel execution, these are independent within each phase:

**Can parallelize:**
- 01, 02, 03 (all CSS/utility changes)
- 11, 12, 13, 14 (separate features)
- 15, 16, 17, 18 (separate features)

**Must be sequential:**
- 07 before 08, 09 (Celebration component reused)
- 08 before 15 (streak display before full logic)
- 19 before 20 (theme before PWA manifest colors)
